bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, November 4, 1889

div1.p: Reed praises Blincoe's bravery after the loss of her husband. He sends money and promises to send more in the future.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Laura Reed Blincoe, November 4, 1889
div1.p:
I
should have written
to you earlier, but
didn't want to send
an empty letter.
After reading your last
letter, Emily & I said,
with one accord, that
you were the greatest
& bravest woman
in North America!
If you can face such
adversity with so
cheerful a heart, we
certainly should never
repine- I think your
determination to go
on pluckily with your
household affairs is
deserving of all praise
& assistance- I wish
I could send something
more deserving- I regret
very much that it is
so pitiful a sum,
but it will help to
put something in your
new pantry or buy
shoes for your dear
little ones against
the coming of winter-
The check was what
remained after paying
October's Expenses- I
have been delaying
writing in order to
see what I would
have- I wish it was
more- It certainly
shan't be the last-
How do you get along
my darling sister? Do
you want a servant?
If so, hire one by all
means, & I will gladly
foot the bill-

If I have not written,
I have not forgotten you.
In my prayers I always
commend you & your dear
ones to the tender care
of a merciful God!
Keep up a brave heart,
my darling Sister, & all
will go well- Emily
& baby join me in best
love to you & each of your
dear ones-

Please write very
soon, if only a word or
two, to your loving brother
